title: Do I Need to Buy a Physical Soroban? App vs. Real Abacus
description: Every parent asks: should I buy a real soroban or is the app enough? Here's the honest answer based on how kids actually learn.

content.intro: When I started my son on soroban, I immediately thought I needed to buy a physical abacus. After 6 months of learning, here's what I've discovered about physical vs. app-based practice.

sections.text: A physical soroban is helpful but NOT required. Most kids learn perfectly well with just an app. If you want one, a basic $10-15 model works great.

items: **Tactile feedback:** Feeling beads click can help beginners
**No screen time:** Good for families limiting devices
**Traditional experience:** Connect to centuries of history
**No distractions:** Can't get notifications on a wooden frame
**Show-and-tell:** Kids love bringing it to school
**Instant feedback:** Knows if answer is right immediately
**Progress tracking:** See stats, streaks, improvement
**Gamification:** Rewards, levels, motivation built-in
**Always available:** No need to carry anything
**Guided lessons:** Step-by-step instruction
**Anzan mode:** Transitions to mental math seamlessly

sections.text: We bought a cheap $12 soroban from Amazon for the first week. My son played with it, understood how it worked, felt the beads. Then we transitioned to the app for daily practice.
Now, 6 months later, the physical soroban sits in a drawer. He does 100% of his practice on the app because:

items: He likes the points and rewards
It tracks his streaks automatically
I can see his progress without asking
He can practice anywhere (waiting rooms, car rides, etc.)

sections.text: When a Physical Soroban Helps Most

items: **Very first week:** Understanding how beads move
**Kinesthetic learners:** Kids who need to touch things
**Screen-limited families:** When device time is restricted
**Competitions:** Some in-person contests use real sorobans
**Showing off:** Kids love demonstrating to friends

sections.text: If budget is tight, skip the physical soroban entirely. The app simulates it accurately. Your money is better spent on consistent practice time.

faq.question: What physical soroban should I buy?
faq.answer: A basic 13 or 17-rod plastic soroban for $10-15 is fine. No need for expensive wooden ones – they don't help kids learn faster.

faq.question: Will my child miss out without a physical soroban?
faq.answer: No. The mental visualization (anzan) is the ultimate goal, and the app trains this just as well – arguably better because of the transition modes.

faq.question: Can I use a Chinese abacus instead?
faq.answer: The Chinese suanpan has a different bead configuration (2+5 vs 1+4). It works but most apps use Japanese soroban style. Better to match what the app uses.

cta.text: Our app includes a virtual soroban that works just like the real thing.
